title: Kenya: Hope for Industry As School Films Recognised
text:
Kenya: KDF Troops Kill 15 Al-Shabaab Terrorists in Somalia, Destroy Operations Base By Anthony Njagi The Kenyan film industry's future looks bright after 10 films from the Kenya Schools and Colleges festivals were nominated for the Out of Africa International Film Festival. This has given hope to industry players that the film and television scene in the country will never lack in material as the students have shown unmatched zeal and enthusiasm in making world-class films. Some of the film trailers have been uploaded on Youtube under the title of Afpeik films. Out of Africa International Film Festival was formed with a goal to provide a platform that brings together global independent filmmakers, producers, promoters and other stakeholders in a common space to explore their stories freely and market the films to a global audience. This year Kamandura Girls' High School scooped the top honours in the screenplay category with a titillating and well directed, acted and produced piece called Anti-Dre. The winning film in the Kenya Schools and Colleges National Drama Festival is about a girl who has had a rough upbringing and neglect from her drug addicted mother. Luckily, Cathy gets sponsored to high school. While in school, she starts a dance group called Anti-Dre, which she uses to educate her peers about the negative effects of drugs abuse. The Film features Gift Terry (Sylvia), Sharon Kasandi (Tess), Sharon Gitonga (Shiru) and Phylis Wamaitha as Msupa.
